Kent Beck wrote:
> It seems clear to me that some sort of test classification scheme is a
> reasonable thing to add to JUnit. However, rather than simply copy one of
> the models out there we're going to go back to first principles and try to
> derive a model for classification that is concise, useful, flexible, and,
> above all, easy to use.
> 
> I've heard two purposes for classification:
> * Performance
> * Assumptions

For me classification gives me the ability to do appropriate slicing
and dicing of my tests to:
* maximize the information the tests can provide to me
* maximize my ability to manage risk in flexible ways

If I can slice my tests into unit, integration, acceptance etc and
check what code coverage each return, that tells me a lot more than
just an aggregate. A project with 100% coverage aggregate but with
10% coverage coming from unit, and 10% from integration and the
rest from acceptance will be vastly different from one that has
100% from unit and none for the others and different too to one that
has 100% coverage for all three.

As an aside, I have seen large projects with 100% unit coverage and
100% acceptance test coverage but never one with 100% integration 
level coverage - but you'll understand what I mean. Also, I used 100%
coverage in the above example but that was just an example - I don't
advocate 100% line or branch coverage as a magical metric we should
necessarily be striving for above all else.

I can do some classification with naming conventions but having arbitrary
groups provides more flexibility. I don't think you need to go over
board here though, I don't need really fined grained flexibility here.
If you want that you are better off looking at what Clover 2 or Agitar
dashboard do by bringing other measures of risk into the picture.

The same applies for CI systems. If I can slice and dice my tests, then
I can better manage risk. I may run all my fast tests and a selection
of very targeted acceptance and integration tests on every check in.
I may run a broader set of tests for high-risk areas several times a day.
I may run a complete regression suite nightly.

I don't see having the ability to slice and dice the test suites in
flexible ways as a hack but as a management tool that allows me to weigh
up fast feedback cycles vs risk vs available hardware resources.

Cheers, Paul.
